channel.title: Victor Villas' Feed
channel.description: The combined feed of my online stuff.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
This ORTBO episode was to me the worst episode of both seasons so far, by a large margin. The directors seem to be losing the seriousness and gravity the first season had.

—
Severance Season 2 Episode 4

item.title: Comment
item.description:
Fifth day in Brazil.

Being an expat is ever stranger. I do feel home. The birds, the food, smiles, slangs, the plants, flowers, sand. The car I used to drive. Muscle memory kicks in. It all feels like it should. Even the clouds look as if they had been broken and are now fixed.

But I also feel like a visitor. The heat, the traffic, inequality. It’s the same as always, but also worse than it was. It’s strange to so easily overhear, to invisibly connect so fast.

item.title: Wants to watch
item.description:
wants to watch Arthur Erickson: Beauty Between The Lines
A local celebrity in Vancouver, though I can’t say I’m a huge fan of most of his work really. It’s hard to separate what’s his design from what came from generic projects done by his company using his name.

item.title: Finished reading
item.description:
finished reading Invisible Cities 🌕🌕🌕🌕🌕
So humbling in its immense creativity and captivating writing. So immersive in its rendering of all that could be otherwise, the world of imagination and dreams and nightmares. So provocative in its resonance of the myriad lives of all peoples, all struggles and passions, laughter and cries. A book to feast upon as many times as I can afford in this life - it is said it's a different book every time you come back to it, and I'm already wondering what's it going to taste like next time.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
The inferno of the living is not something that will be; if there is one, it is what is already here, the inferno where we live every day, that we form by being together. There are two ways to escape suffering it. The first is easy for many: accept the inferno and become such a part of it that you can no longer see it. The second is risky and demands constant vigilance and apprehension: seek and learn to recognize who and what, in the midst of the inferno, are not inferno, then make them endure, give them space.

—
Invisible Cities

item.title: Finished reading
item.description:
finished reading Playing Possum 🌕🌕🌕🌕🌗
As a non biologist, this book was a super interesting listen for the compilation of studies regarding animal behavior and the respective anthropomorphism/anthropectomy we tend to color them. This is the rare non-fiction book that does NOT draw the reader towards The One Book mindset - where a concept is overstretched until it becomes a hammer capable of nailing all screws known to humankind.

I think the structural design of the book works well. As expected from a philosopher, the thesis is built from the ground up and a lot of effort is put into what these concepts are _not_ saying. I like it, but I can imagine that readers not used to the extra precision and nitpicking common to philosophy writers will find it a bit dry or dense at times.

The one small gripe I have is that after all this effort, the final chapter ends up playing like a shortcut. The case for animals having a concept of death brought by the distinction between tonic immobility and thanatosis (faking death, aka playing possum) and what this tells us about predators is mostly not dependant on the framework the book invests in building. It's such a strong case, it feels like the core issue is answered by reading the first two or three chapters plus the last one, and everything in between is superfluous - but even the filler was very interesting to me, so it was time well spent anyway.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
Hey @TechConnectify, saw your video today and found this other related content. If you have some time to kill reading a personal account from someone experiencing the extremes of algorithmic complacency:

https://thewalrus.ca/at-3-a-m-i-turned-to-ai-for-comfort-that-was-my-first-mistake/

Side note, I just sent you this using "Quiet public", which is a badly publicized "hide post from search and trends" flag.

item.title: Finished watching
item.description:
finished watching Old 🌕🌕🌑🌑🌑
An interesting premise baited me into watching something I should have known better, given the trailer already shows a jumble of fodder characters.

Some lines of dialogue are straight up garbage. Also, what a shit touch to portray the therapist with totally useless interjections. Someone in this film crew doesn't seem to believe this to be a real profession.

The plot tries too hard. I was willing to accept the selective effects of the aging vs growing with the unnecessary addition of high speed scarring, along the mysterious blockade that impedes people from leaving. That's a bit too out there already in terms of bio sci fi, but workable as a premise. But it gets murkier on the details, like the specifics of some deaths.

And apparently this multi-billion dollar company and its scientists are smart enough to develop a cure for epilepsy but cannot find a way to plug a coral reef. If it's safe to swim out of the beach using it, it shouldn't be hard to hire an unsuspecting diver to plug it, or at least install better surveillance on it?

And who is in charge of tidying up the beach? The most fantastical feature of this geography would not be its aging properties but the capacity to fully reset the entire surface of the beach from any sort of remains from the previous cohort, without human intervention, while still keeping a bunch of things close to the rocks easy to dig up. Imagine the odds

item.title: Finished watching
item.description:
finished watching Oblivion 🌕🌕🌗🌑🌑
Airplane rewatch. Entertaining, even if not one of the greats. Great visuals, good acting. Some of the tropes are glaring and tiring. The New Yorker military grade man that builds his promised lake house for a romance that survives memory wiping technology. The plot core is decent sci fi, but several gaps make it easy target for criticism. Almost everything surrounding the scavengers is a bit of a mess, and the apparent stinginess in deploying drones, and the on and off surveillance capabilities of the enemies.

The ending is the weakest bit. The movie wrecks its already shaky defensibility by adding a totally unnecessary time skip, just to present us a kid. It’s basic and kind of stupid how that unfolds (and its implications).

item.title: Comment
item.description:
“This government does not represent us”

Yes it does, it’s literally called representative democracy.

I have been there before (Bolsonaro), and while I get the #NotMyPresident chant, this cannot be used to excuse oneself from the consequences of these representatives.

“I did not vote for this” isn’t a free pass, it’s the bare minimum.

item.title: Started watching
item.description:
started watching North of North 🌕🌕🌕🌕🌑
The showcase of Inuk culture and the life at Nunavut is super interesting and the series even packs a few not so subtle punches on the relationship between Canadian institutions and native peoples. It's sometimes corny and predictable, but at the same time every episode has a fresh and unique touch.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
Great piece.

https://thewalrus.ca/common-sense-politics

How to reconcile the anti-intellectualism that serves as a foundation for the denial of science with the apparent technocratic positivism behind the defense of tech oligarchs?

The answer is grievance. #Politics of resentment. An angry bunch is an engaged bunch.

It's so funny when these random cross-overs happen. Makes the web feel like a small place from time to time. Well, the group of cool people saying cool stuff might be in fact a small corner.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
This Friday for the first time I took a #seaplane from #Vancouver to #VictoriaBC. It's incredible. Beautiful scenery, downtown to downtown in 35 minutes, check-in in 20 minutes - quicker than BC Ferries as a pedestrian... The noise isn't as bad as I thought, but it's still a solid 90 dB so an earplug is welcome.

The worst of it is the smell and the pollution from the fuel, and obviously the price. It's ten times the price of public transit for the route, but it's nearly ten times faster!

item.title: Comment
item.description: Unfortunately what I need isn’t really photography, which is what all three federated services deliver. My main needs are 1) Stories, 2) Highlights, 3) carousel posts mixing image and video. That’s the state of the art that would make an #Instagram replacement for me.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
Discovered another #PixelfedAlternative besides frequency.app thanks to @bluszcz

The vernissage.photos and the Impressia iOS app. It looks like they were related but split in two separate projects? These seem even more focused on photography.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
#Pixelfed seems to have good momentum, as dan continues to churn out code at a wild pace.

Still, it’s still quite not there as an Instagram replacement for me, and I’m afraid the project is competing for attention with Loops, the other project from same author.

So I have been looking for alternatives, and today I found out about @frequency: open source backend is a mastodon fork, polished app, friendly and sensible maintainers. Following it closely 👀 https://mastodon.social/@jesseplusplus/113891449411033309

item.title: Comment
item.description:
My Hummingbird #portafilter by Canal arrived, and once again I have been duped by an #espresso #coffee product #Kickstarter that simply doesn't deliver. It's not entirely garbage, but it's not what I signed up for. Very disappointing.

How many more of these am I going to fall for before understanding that pre-ordering things is unnecessary risk... is a mystery that eludes my selfawarewolf.

item.title: Comment
item.description:
OK, kind of giving up on #Pixelfed for videos for now. Video format hassles and UI complications aside, I just realized that video posts are not federating and are not visible in the RSS feed.

This combination is a dealbreaker for an #Instagram replacement for me, so I guess I’ll be dumping would-be stories into Mastodon directly for a while to see how it goes.

item.title: Finished reading
item.description:
finished reading AI Superpowers 🌕🌕🌕🌑🌑
I like that the book presents a point of view that helps me understand a bit more the government role and technology development in China, escaping from the monolithic Silicon Valley ideology that embodies most talk about innovation and government intervention in "the west". If you don't read much about China and/or most of what you read related to Startups is from the USA, this is a good break from the gospel of "the lean startup" and the tyranny of infinitely scalable SaaS.

It was a bit rough to finish the read, though. It gets repetitive often, so I had a recurring feeling that the book could be half as long. There are few problematic points the author glosses over: capitalizing on poverty and precarious work conditions, cutthroat competition as role model, success measured by size and power. These might happen to be Dr. Lee's own personal biases slipping through. But in the end this discomfort might be a reflection of my own western bias, as I had a hard time ignoring the differences in values when studying a mostly strategic analysis on growth and innovation.

item.title: Started reading
item.description:
started reading AI Superpowers

item.title: Finished reading
item.description:
finished reading The Beatles 🌕🌕🌑🌑🌑
I don't know how to evaluate Bob Spitz work, whether it's accurate or simplistic, but it feels well researched and based on credible records. I guess it was a fine work, but the experience of listening to this audiobook wasn't that great, coming from someone that was mildly curious. There's only so much one can do to spice up a bibliography that doesn't derail into fiction. Halfway through I was listening the audiobook on 1.75x not really caring if something got lost.

I did learn a thing or two. John was a self absorbed dickhead; Paul was a bit nicer but not by a long margin; Gorge was stuck under their shadow; and Ringo was surviving the ride. They were brilliant musicians, very misguided and suggestible to bullshit. Understandable, considering their context and the whirlwind that must be becoming world famous in your early twenties.

This was the ultimate Beatles read, in the sense that I don't plan on ever reading anything about them ever again.

item.title: Started reading
item.description:
started reading The Beatles
My father loves The Beatles, and I dig the occasional song that still makes it to the radio. Mildly curious to learn more about their saga.
